## Ê≥¢Êµ™ËÉΩÂèëÁîµ

## Check List

**Please read and check followings before submitting a PR.**

- [ ] I want to publish my theme on Hexo official website.
  - [ ] I have read the [theme publishing doc](https://hexo.io/docs/themes#Publishing).
  - [ ] `name` is unique.
  - [ ] `link` URL is correct.
  - [ ] `preview` URL is correct.
  - [ ] `preview` URL web site is rendered correctly.
  - [ ] Add a screenshot to `source/themes/screenshots`.
  - [ ] Screenshot filename is same as value of `name`.
  - [ ] Screenshot size is `800 * 500`.
  - [ ] Screenshot file format is `png`.
- [ ] I want to publish my plugin on Hexo official website.
  - [ ] I have read the [plugin publishing doc](https://hexo.io/docs/plugins#Publishing).
  - [ ] `name` is unique.
  - [ ] `link` URL is correct.
- [ ] Others (Update, fix, translation, etc...)
  - Languages:
  - [ ] `en` English
  - [ ] `ko` Korean
  - [ ] `pt-br` Brazilian Portuguese
  - [ ] `ru` Russian
  - [ ] `th` Thai
  - [ ] `zh-cn` simplified Chinese
  - [ ] `zh-tw` traditional Chinese

[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'Haroenv', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2018-05-18 16:05:49+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'I'm not sure why this is happening, but when I have malformed front matter, Hugo throws an error and stops, but doesn't actually have a status code other than 0. 

```
Started building sites ...
ERROR 2018/05/18 18:04:01 failed to parse page metadata for "widgets/powered-by.md": yaml: line 39: found unexpected document indicator
Error: Error building site: Errors reading pages: Error: failed to parse page metadata for "widgets/powered-by.md": yaml: line 39:found unexpected document indicator for powered-by.md
```

Here is `$0` actually `0`. 

I'm also using `hugo-cli` (from npm) with 0.40.3 set as the Hugo version to use. 

Error seems to be generated 

https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/blob/b2b500f563c3bb36751a4c1610df113c4daad604/hugolib/page.go#L1747

but I don't know if this is supposed to be swallowed like that. 

Thanks√ß!', 'title': 'Hugo errors with exit code 0', 'type': 'issue'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'bep', 'comment_id': 390277729.0, 'datetime': '2018-05-18 17:31:11+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_1', 'text': "I just tested this, and I cannot reproduce it. Are you sure you don't have any other tool that swallows this exit code? Gulp? Can you test it by invoking Hugo directly from the shell?", 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}

 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'McInkay', 'comment_id': 436944767.0, 'datetime': '2018-11-08 10:19:31+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_2', 'text': "I'm having this situation myself, I have a malformed md file, but it's returning an exit code of 0.

I was running with yarn, but when I remove yarn and run it manually, it still has the same issue.

[Here's the build](https://circleci.com/gh/YaManicKill/pdd/31)

[And here's the code you can clone if you want to test it](https://github.com/YaManicKill/pdd/tree/fix-error-code). The branch fix-error-code has changed the circleci build to not use yarn and has an error in one of the md files, you should just be able to run hugo on that branch and see that it is returning 0 exit code.

Or do you want me to open a new ticket?", 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}]
column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Hugo errors with exit code 0
username_0: I'm not sure why this is happening, but when I have malformed front matter, Hugo throws an error and stops, but doesn't actually have a status code other than 0. 

```
Started building sites ...
ERROR 2018/05/18 18:04:01 failed to parse page metadata for "widgets/powered-by.md": yaml: line 39: found unexpected document indicator
Error: Error building site: Errors reading pages: Error: failed to parse page metadata for "widgets/powered-by.md": yaml: line 39:found unexpected document indicator for powered-by.md
```

Here is `$0` actually `0`. 

I'm also using `hugo-cli` (from npm) with 0.40.3 set as the Hugo version to use. 

Error seems to be generated 

https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/blob/b2b500f563c3bb36751a4c1610df113c4daad604/hugolib/page.go#L1747

but I don't know if this is supposed to be swallowed like that. 

Thanks√ß!
<issue_comment>username_1: I just tested this, and I cannot reproduce it. Are you sure you don't have any other tool that swallows this exit code? Gulp? Can you test it by invoking Hugo directly from the shell?
<issue_comment>username_0: Running ‚Äúyarn Hugo‚Äù also swallows error codes, but that‚Äôs still with ‚ÄúHugo-cli‚Äù, the error might be there<issue_closed>
<issue_comment>username_1: OK, you need to report this with those libraries.
<issue_comment>username_2: I'm having this situation myself, I have a malformed md file, but it's returning an exit code of 0.

I was running with yarn, but when I remove yarn and run it manually, it still has the same issue.

[Here's the build](https://circleci.com/gh/YaManicKill/pdd/31)

[And here's the code you can clone if you want to test it](https://github.com/YaManicKill/pdd/tree/fix-error-code). The branch fix-error-code has changed the circleci build to not use yarn and has an error in one of the md files, you should just be able to run hugo on that branch and see that it is returning 0 exit code.

Or do you want me to open a new ticket?

column5: [{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'simardcasanova', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2019-01-26 13:55:20+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'Hi everyone, first of all, I want to say how useful and great RSS Bridge is! I use it on a daily basis, and it's a powerful and easy to use tool. When used against a Twitter profile, emojis are displayed in a really large size, which distracts a little bit while reading the tweet. Here is an example: I don't know if this also happens with other bridges. The screenshot was done on Tiny Tiny RSS, but with News Explorer (on macOS) the issue is also there. For reference or replication, here is the tweet in the screenshot: https://twitter.com/username_0/status/1088950943658446848. And I use my own RSS Bridge instance at https://feeder.aleryon.science. Is it a bug in RSS Bridge, or something that is misconfigured in my instance? Thank you!', 'title': 'Emojis in tweets', 'type': 'issue'} {'action': 'created', 'author': 'fulmeek', 'comment_id': 457910391.0, 'datetime': '2019-01-27 11:39:45+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_1', 'text': "After digging the code, I just realized that this issue was already fixed two years ago. It is even done the way I suggested above. it's just that Firefox appears to strip all style attributes from feed items when I inspect it there, that's why I thought this is missing. But it's present in the output source. So, if these emojis are displayed larger, your feed reader probably strips style attributes, so this solution does not have any effect then.", 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'} {'action': 'created', 'author': 'simardcasanova', 'comment_id': 462176046.0, 'datetime': '2019-02-10 21:31:02+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': "Thanks for the feedback! I'm closing the issue as from RSS Bridge's point of view, it is solved (no more can be done).", 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'} {'action': 'closed', 'author': 'simardcasanova', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2019-02-10 21:31:03+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': '', 'title': None, 'type': 'issue'}]
column6: Title: Emojis in tweets username_0: Hi everyone, first of all, I want to say how useful and great RSS Bridge is! I use it on a daily basis, and it's a powerful and easy to use tool. When used against a Twitter profile, emojis are displayed in a really large size, which distracts a little bit while reading the tweet. Here is an example: I don't know if this also happens with other bridges. The screenshot was done on Tiny Tiny RSS, but with News Explorer (on macOS) the issue is also there. For reference or replication, here is the tweet in the screenshot: https://twitter.com/username_0/status/1088950943658446848. And I use my own RSS Bridge instance at https://feeder.aleryon.science. Is it a bug in RSS Bridge, or something that is misconfigured in my instance? Thank you! username_1: After digging the code, I just realized that this issue was already fixed two years ago. It is even done the way I suggested above. it's just that Firefox appears to strip all style attributes from feed items when I inspect it there, that's why I thought this is missing. But it's present in the output source. So, if these emojis are displayed larger, your feed reader probably strips style attributes, so this solution does not have any effect then. username_0: Thanks for the feedback! I'm closing the issue as from RSS Bridge's point of view, it is solved (no more can be done).

Title: Cannot add collaborator - Invitation not found username_0: I'm trying to add staticmanapp as a collaborator to my repository (https://github.com/username_0/blog), but whenever I've tried to go accept the invite by either https://api.staticman.net/v2/connect/username_0/blog or https://api.staticman.net/v2/connect/eeemil/blog (for trying case sensitivity) it just says "Invitation not found". ![screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7189109/44958472-02a45980-aee1-11e8-9868-19442856725d.png) username_1: I have also been facing this issue. If it helps, mine is a private repo. username_0: When I tried https://api.staticman.net/v2/connect/username_0/blog again ~18 hours later, it worked and I received an OK. For me, the issue is resolved but I'll wait for a developer to mark this as solved if this issue is affecting more people. Perhaps there is a delay from inviting staticmanapp untill the invite can be accepted? If so, this should be documented on https://staticman.net/docs/ username_1: I think this is an intermittent server load problem, since I am still getting the invitation not found error. username_2: I am facing the same problem username_1: Mine was also automatically resolved in a day or so. I guess there's a waiting list. username_3: I have the same problem. I sent the invitation 18 hours ago, and using the accept link, I've received the JSON message "Too many requests in this time frame", and a date for the next allowed request. I reloaded the page, and the "Invitation not found" message appeared. Now, same steps happen: first a JSON message, "Too many requests...", and in second page load, "Invitation not found"... Still I don't have the invitation accepted. username_2: Its been two days, and still `invitation pending` or `too many requests`. If @username_10 may check for the issue (he is the creator of staticman). username_4: Same here :) username_5: I have the same issue. It just returns "Invitation not found". username_6: I also get "Invitation not found". Looks like I have to wait. username_7: Me too... keep getting the same "Invitation not found"... username_8: Same thing here also. Two test sites and the invitations are not found. username_9: Same here, did anyone got it sorted? username_10: Sorry, I‚Äôm AFK for a few days, but I‚Äôll have a look when I get back on Sunday or Monday. The ‚ÄúToo many requests‚Äù is a message from the GitHub API indicating that we‚Äôre over the limit, I wonder if the ‚ÄúInvitation not found‚Äù is a similar thing, i.e. the user being added to too many repos. username_9: Thank you Eduardo, boas ferias ;) username_11: no response from me either... username_11: does anyone have any updates on this issue? username_3: I got `OK` two days ago. Perhaps this is an intermitent issue... username_8: I never got `OK`... More than a week of waiting... username_12: If this issue is urgent, why don't consider [setting up your own API instance](https://www.flyinggrizzly.net/2017/12/setting-up-staticman-server/)? Provided you have a (free) Heroku account, [the whole setup](https://vincenttam.gitlab.io/post/2018-09-16-staticman-powered-gitlab-pages/2/) can be done under fifteen minutes. username_13: Indeed, this is also the described solution in https://github.com/username_10/staticman/issues/222. However, it is not explicitely described anywhere yet, and reduces the appeal quite a bit. As far as I'm concerned, I would rather pay a small fee than deploy my own. username_12: As a consequence of [@username_10's request](https://github.com/username_10/staticman/pull/219#issuecomment-417657297), I've really built [one running on a free Heroku dyno](https://staticman3.herokuapp.com) to test the newly available #219 GitLab suuport. The associated Git* bots are both named @staticmanlab. username_13: (Sorry, I wasn't talking about the deployment process, for which you've given an excellent and totally clear link, I was talking about the Staticman getting started: it doesn't mention these potential API limit problems yet.) username_12: @username_13 I see your point. It's better to mention this limitation at the very beginning, so that users can choose between 1. use public API instance 2. setup own API instance This is more efficient as @staticmanapp will receive less invitations. username_14: This still happened to me after waiting for five days. The response is still 'invitation not found'. Is there any workaround for this? Thanks username_12: @username_14 As depicted on Staticman's set, Staticman functions basically like a :truck: truck which POSTs HTML :page_facing_up: form data into your GitHub/GitLab repo :file_folder: (running on any GitHub/GitLab server). When a bus is not working, passengers would be asked to take another one. Similarly, for a _workaround_, you can use [_my API instance_](https://staticman3.herokuapp.com) (built at the request of @username_10 for testing #219) or even [build your own instance](https://www.flyinggrizzly.net/2017/12/setting-up-staticman-server/) within Heroku's free tier. username_12: @username_14 To bypass this invitation problem, why not try GitLab Pages? In GitLab, there's no such invitation mechanism---you just add the bot (say @staticmanlab) into the contributing members. If you really love open source, migrating from the _proprietary_ GitHub to _open souce_ GitLab, which has _native_ CD/CI support, will free you from the aforementioned GitHub API limit. username_12: @username_2 I don't know about that, but a quick search points me to a GitLab forum question "* Does GitLab have an API rate limit*". The last comment lists out several endpoints which controls the traffic. Hope that helps. The last question is precisely the problem. Now the :truck: is overloaded. One may either wait (for an indefinite time period) for a larger truck, or build his/her own one. Building the former costs surely a fortune, while building the later for a personal blog can be free. username_13: It would be nice to have a breakdown of the usage. Does somebody really believe that there's enough Staticman-powered websites for the bot to hit 5k requests an hour? I have a feeling that if anything, it is a spam problem that we have. username_2: @username_12 Furthur exploring the link in the last comment that you mentioned, points thay GitLab indeed have api request limit ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17742733/46062276-e8c80080-c186-11e8-8633-e47fd728dca9.png) Also mentioned [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38478806/does-gitlab-api-have-a-rate-limit) **Which means it is a matter of time when enough people use someone's GitLab api and hit 600 req/min.** Looks like self hosted instance for your personal use only is the safe option, **BUT** that too only upto the limit that the number of users commenting on your self hosted staticman api should not collectively generates more than 600 req/min. username_14: This is a matter of scalability indeed. Maybe we'll end up building federated commenting (API) system where people can build their API servers (with their request limits) and join them with existing ones. Also, if @username_2 picture says 600 req/min/IP that's actually good enough for normal people because one IP should have less than 600 requests per minute. username_2: but only if they have deployed their own personal api instance. If group of staticman users ends up using the same api, the limit will be easily achieved. As mentioned by @username_12 [here ](https://github.com/username_10/staticman/issues/227#issuecomment-424495509) about the steps of deployment, it is still not easy for majority of people. username_13: Wait, what? Let's say 50 people use the same deployment. 600 req/min / 50 sites = 12 requests per minute per site. That means at the end of the week, each site would have received a maximum of 12\*60\*24\*7 = 120k comments. The same math applied to GitHub means 50 sites each get a maximum of 16k comments per week. On my most visited website (800-1000 daily visits), I get maximum 10 comments a week. I have Staticman running on 3 sites so in the end even that 'high figure' gets drowned into a very low average of 3. Am I missing something or is some spammer abusing the tool? username_2: üëç Thanks for the math part. Honestly I didn't calculate the numbers when commenting. Even 12 request per minute per site can be a bottleneck at the peak time of the site visit (only for some very interesting article/site). (Please note I don't have any research fact) With the growing popularity of staticman, there can be more than 50 people using some specific api instance (this is what happening now with @staticmanapp on github). I am sure with the use of reCaptcha with staticman, spamming is negligible. username_13: 50 was just an example to show we have an extremely large comments per minute / site ratio at our disposal. Yet people have been consistently unable to add Staticman as a collaborator for a month. In my opinion, either we have too many unmaintained sites that weren't set up with captchas and get spam, or somebody is deliberately bricking the instance. username_2: If someone deliberately bricking it, the best way is -- hitting the api from different IPs concurrently to reach the limit per minute using `https://api.staticman.net/v2/entry/{GITHUB USERNAME}/{GITHUB REPOSITORY}}` In any-case we need data/log (if available) of @staticmanapp to find out the cause. username_13: Excellent catch, @username_12. I vote for adding a captcha or an Akismet key to that site. username_2: @username_12 Allow me to correct, by commits if you mean pull requests. Since there are only 30 commits out of which only few are caused by staticman comment entry. However, there are > 3000 pull requests caused by staticman, but spanned over last two months. There are only 13 pull requests in the lat 24 hours. I am sure this is not the cause for eating away of API quota. username_13: I just spammed said form a little and noticed that while I still can't add Staticman to my repository, my comments got through just fine. What the hell is going on? If we're hitting the API limit, we would hit it for all cases. username_12: @username_2 @username_13 Thannks for doing the math. In fact, since the public (production and development and my own) API instances are powered by Heroku apps, they are subject to *both* Heroku and GitHub/GitLab's limits. From it's server response time to a GET request to `/`, the first instance _isn't_ run on the free dyno, whereas the other two _are_. From a server-side point of view, the traffic from GET requests to `/` and `/favicon.ico` and POST requests with status 500 (possibly due to GitHub/GitLab repo owners who wish to test/use Staticman) are also considerable. Since the documentation for Staticman v3 in #219 has not yet been integrated to the official site, it's possible that a user *has forgotten to supply the Git service provider* when firing a POST request to the `/entry` endpoint, like POST /entry/v3/user/repo/branch/property (wrong URL!) he/she may keep trying until he/she hits status 427 "too many requests" or he/she gets tired of status 500 "internal server error". For the case of the public production instance (still running v2), it has to handle requests with _wrong_ endpoint path/request body from GitHub repo owners, who might fire (a multitude of invalid POST) requests over a short period of time. Lacking knowledge in networking, while testing Staticman with [a sample GitHub repo](https://git.io/fxf18), I've tried sending POST requests from the famous RESTclient, but all of them _failed_ with a status 500. Finally, I've given up those request clients and coded a HTML form. As a result, the project has been expanded to a [minimal Jekyll+Staticman v3 GitHub Pages](https://git.io/smdemo). ![staticman-ok](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5748535/46254851-fe466e80-c495-11e8-94f3-e515bd79aa31.png) Looking back, if I had kept trying RESTclient, I might have hit the bottleneck of my own API instance _without_ building anything. username_15: I'm also having the same issue when contacting the API - I'm getting "Invitation not found" although I submitted one a couple of hours earlier. So there's no solution yet except to host your own API? username_15: @username_12 Thanks for the advice! Since switching to GitLab wasn't an option for me, I instantiated my own version of the Staticman API. It was actually quite easy thanks to your great description in your [blog post](https://vincenttam.gitlab.io/post/2018-09-16-staticman-powered-gitlab-pages/2/). To share my experience, I just wrote a [blog post about getting the Staticman API running and getting the commenting system working for Hugo](https://www.datascienceblog.net/post/other/staticman_comments/). username_16: Perhaps we'll go the self-hosted route, having same issues here and unresolved after a week. username_17: Thanks this will be helpful username_18: At first attempt, haven't dug in deeper, getting an RSA error Key not Found error thrown after npm start. username_18: @username_12 altered a bit, using netlify.toml instead of Procfile as wanting to run on Netlify instead. But yeah I checked that article out. username_13: @username_18 wait, can you keep an NPM process alive from a Netlify build? With the free plan? I thought this was meant to build static sites only. username_12: @username_15 When I read your old reply the second time, I find your reason for setting up a custom API instance ("switching to GitLab wasn't an option") *misleading*. In fact, the *same* API instancebcan handle multiple Git service providers. Again, please refer to my demos. 1. Minimal Jekyll GitHub Pages at https://git.io/smdemo 2. Minimal Hugo GitLab pages at https://vincenttam.gitlab.io/test-hugo-staticman For the correct URL schemes, please refer to #219. username_19: I having the same issue. I am either getting "Invitation not found" or "too many requests". username_12: @username_19 In your repo username_19/Blog/docs/_docs/18-history.md, it's written that custom Staticman API path is allowed, thanks to @username_13, who has contributed to mmistakes/minimal-mistakes#1842. From #239, it seems that @staticmanapp is taking a holiday for the moment. #222 suggests building one's own API instance, whereas #219, which resolves #22, allows us to *bypass this problem by switching to GitLab*. (You may click on the link above to my sample Staticman demo on GitLab.) P.S. Searching [#staticman](https://github.com/search?o=desc&q=%23staticman&s=stars&type=Repositories) on GitHub, I've found that okfde/edulabs#555 is generated by @staticwalrus. Maybe you can find a temporary workaround from this. I prefer switching to the *free* GitLab though. username_19: How do I make my own staticman instance. username_20: Hey everyone, It has started to worry me that I may have some misconfguration somewhere. After about three days, I am still getting the 'Invitation not found'. I have studied the code in 'connect.js' file to understand how the API end point responses to the connect requests. It seems like that it looksup my GitHub username and repository and if it can't find it, throws the error I mentioned above. There is a process/method in that file called 'getRepoInvites'. It's trying to match 'invitation.repository.full_name' with the one been requested. Can anyone shed more light on this or help me understand this more? Thanks, Saeed username_12: @username_20 https://github.com/username_10/staticman/issues/243#issuecomment-450472431 provides a detailed analysis for this problem. It has *integrated* CD/CI, which greatly simplified setup for Hugo blogs. (On GitHub, you need a third-party CD/CI service for Hugo sites.) (this includes people saying me too and stuff) username_12: Since the problem is ongoing, I _don't_ think closing this issue is appropriate. The workarounds are ways to help people to enjoy this great service despite Staticman's API limit. Since the documentation has not described them, it's natural that users ask questions about them. Instead of closing this issue and hiding them in the closed tab, we should let them stay there until the problem is resolved. More importantly, the decentralization of Staticman's API allows netizens to enjoy this service in countries where some Google and Facebook are forbidden. Hence, through the discussion of the workarounds, some users enjoy greater freedom when using Staticman. This phenomenon should be embraced instead of feared. username_22: i have the same issue... and after 1 month not worked username_12: @username_22 You may find this repo useful: https://github.com/asadise/blog P.S.
